Specific Details: I met briefly with Eamonn Ryan TD and I discussed the need to recycle phosphorus to grow food in a sustainable by making struvite from human urine. I asked him to ask a question in Dáil Éireann
DPOs Lobbied: Eamon Ryan|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas::Roderic O'Gorman|Councillor|Fingal County Council
Subject Matter: I met briefly with Eamonn Ryan TD and I discussed the need to recycle phosphorus to grow food in a sustainable by making struvite from human urine. I asked him to ask a question in Dáil Éireann
Intended Results: To eventually get a change in Part H of the Irish Building Regulations and the EPA Code of Practice for domestic waste water treatment to allow for urine separating toilets and for urine storage. In addition to ask for a national system of treating this urine with Magnesium salts in order to make struvite as a slow release fertilizer for farmers to use as a sustainable fertilizer on land. By so doing to recycle nutrients to grow crops without toxic metals or ingested pharmaceuticals.::A second impact would be to significantly reduce the nutrients from domestic houses in the countryside that end up in the soil after the septic tanks and that eventually percolates into the ground water and eventually the rivers. .::Because phosphorus is a finite mineral found in rocks - the economically recoverable world resource is finite. When this mineral extraction from the mines is unable to keep up with world demand - we may have food price increases and food shortages in certain parts of the world. Eventually when the world resources is completely depleted many will  be using urine anyway as the basis of a low cost fertilizer. Human urine however also contains ingested pharmaceuticals that must be removed.
Lobbying Activities: I also sent e mails to Roderic O'Gorman|Meeting|1

Subject Matter: Commission of Inquiry into Mother and Baby Homes and Certain Related Matters: The Christine Buckley Centre among other agencies working together contacted all depts of the Oireachtas on 5th October and released a press statement in light of the upcoming report release. They launched the Facing The Future Together Report to highlight issues and identified 5 key asks for all Survivors. Our Co-Founder was interviewed on the launch via webinar 9th October and via press.
Intended Results: 5 Key Asks for All Survivors: 1. Global Supports for Survivors based outside Ireland. 2. Services for Families- Accessible Counselling. 3. Health Amendment Act Health Card for All Survivors. 4. Advocacy Support including Public Services with Strong links to Support Services. 5. Trauma Informed Training for All Staff working in customer facing roles on how to identify Survivors and Respond to their unique needs.::From the Christine Buckley Centre to also highlight the need for increased resources and supports to be given to Frontline services who already working directly with Survivors.
Lobbying Activities: After the email was sent on the 5th October a webinar was held on 9th October to launch the Facing the Future Together Report and invites were sent to Members of the Oireachtas, Press and Survivors networks in Ireland. After this panelists from the groups spoke to the press in following weeks. The Oireachtas Members received PDF versions on 5th October and printed hardcopies in the following weeks.|Event / Reception|51-100
Person primarily responsible for lobbyin: Carmel McDonnell Byrne Co-Founder, Manager Nóra Dempsey and Chairperson of the Board Donal Buckley

Subject Matter: To address the lack of not for profit community childcare services in Fingal, and to increase supply.  To seek a specific funding model for not for profit community childcare services in Fingal.

Specific Details: IASW Letter Refugee Program
DPOs Lobbied: Roderic O'Gorman|Minister|Department of Children, Equality, Disability, Integration and Youth
Subject Matter: IASW Letter Refugee Program
Intended Results: All host families should be requested to sign a declaration regarding any criminal history, pending a commitment to full vetting. This process is long used in the placement of children in relative foster placements and provides a basic safety measure which does not delay placement.::While vetting is individual to the organisation who requested it, for expediency, any evidence of participation in vetted activities, along with a letter from the organisation confirming it only accepts fully vetted members is also helpful.::Host families should be encouraged to complete free, already accessible Children First Training and Child Safeguarding Statements could be easily adapted for Host Families.::All Ukrainian families and individuals should be provided with clear information about their rights and clear information about available supports should any incidents of abuse occur. People should be provided with clear information about their host families, including the vetting process used.::Any support organisations involved in providing accommodation and/or related services should be advised of their obligations under Children First to have child safeguarding statements and appropriate procedures in place.::Schools and other childcare facilities involved (as some of the main public services that will be provided to children in this situation) should be provided with relevant information and support, as should the parents of these children be provided with information regarding services provided and opportunities for parents to link with relevant services.

Specific Details: Public Consultation on the next Government Policy Framework for Children and Young People in Ireland
DPOs Lobbied: Roderic O'Gorman|Minister|Department of Children, Equality, Disability, Integration and Youth
Subject Matter: Public Consultation on the next Government Policy Framework for Children and Young People in Ireland
Intended Results: Actions: Youth Work Funding ▪ Invest an additional €10 million in youth work services ▪ Increase the VAT Compensation Scheme for Charities cap from €5 million to €20 million Community Healthcare Centres ▪ Funding for additional services – nutrition, counselling ▪ Increased pay incentives for high-quality consultants to co-locate or relocate in rural outreach centres Drug Use and Addiction Services ▪ Commitment for health-led approach – funding for community mental health services::Actions: Working from Home ▪ Increased geographic coverage of the existing 4G network to address black spots – licensing fee decrease for increased bandwidth allowance for mobile phone companies. ▪ High-Speed broadband is available to all homes throughout Ireland and is upgrading the current mobile network to 5G nationwide. ▪ Access to rural working hubs in each rural town and village to enable remote workers to access social and technical facilities. Third level Admissions::Actions: Youth Employment Activation and Education ▪ Allocate €64.8 million to restore the full rate of Jobseeker’s Allowance to young people under 25 years ▪ Invest €200 million to deliver additional education, training and apprenticeship opportunities and other employment measures::Actions: Road Transport and Car Use ▪ Increased provision of rural 44KW/50KW charging points ▪ Through the Ireland Strategic Investment Fund (ISIF), a government fund would be created and used by the industry to provide low-cost car insurance for young drivers who meet an appropriate and lower risk criteria for 2 years. This model is similar to the SCBI model of low-cost finance, in which the risk is shared by the taxpayer and industry. Criteria-licence type: full. Age: 20-25, no penalty points.::Supporting voluntary organisations and volunteers to deliver support and services to young people. ▪ Increased ambition around access, availability, continuity of youth services for children and young people. ▪ Mental Health and well being ▪ Education, training and life skills development::Greater visibility and more young people feeling comfortable being LGBTQ+. Greater access to community and friends online more consultation with young people about issues that affect them greater awareness and appreciation of the impact of youth work on their lives recognition of mental health impact has increased and young person is more open to talk about their own mental health.::During covid, there was difficulty finding volunteers. Funding and resources are needed to help reactivate volunteerism campaigns. More funding and resources need to support young people with mental health issues following covid. Important to keep consulting with young people to ask them about the impacts of COVID. NYCI research is a good reference here. There has been serious burnout of volunteers and staff within youth organisations.
Person primarily responsible for lobbyin: Gillian Richardson, Acting Head of Policy

DPOs Lobbied: Minister Malcolm Noonan |TD|Department of Housing, Planning, Community and Local Government::Eamon Ryan|Minister|Department of Environment, Climate and Communications::Pippa Hackett|Minister of State|Department of Agriculture, Food and the Marine::Steven Matthews TD|TD|Department of Housing, Local Government and Heritage::Brian Leddin|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas::Catherine Martin|Minister|Department of Tourism, Culture, Arts, Gaeltacht, Sport and Media::Joe O'Brien|Minister of State|Department of Rural and Community Development::Roderic O'Gorman|Minister|Department of Children, Equality, Disability, Integration and Youth::Pippa Hackett|Minister of State|Department of Agriculture, Food and the Marine::Ossian Smyth|Minister of State|Department of Public Expenditure and Reform::Patrick Costello|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas::Francis Noel Duffy|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas::Róisín Garvey|Senator|Seanad::Pauline O'Reilly|Senator|Seanad
Subject Matter: Proposal for urine separating toilets in 200 new houses. Proposal that Uisce Éireann collects the urine. Proposal that phosphorus as struvite from separated urine be recovered and recycled to food crops
Intended Results: To demonstrate and develop the recycling of phosphorus as Struvite from urine in Ireland. Confirm by testing that the struvite produced from separated urine is the most toxin-free and metal-free form of recycled phosphorus fertiliser for food crops. Seek certification with the European Union to obtain the CE mark for this type of struvite because of the practically undetectable levels of toxic metals or residual pharmaceuticals in the fertiliser.   ::To begin to take steps to create an indigenous pure phosphorus recycling industry and market in Ireland, based on separated urine. ::To efficiently prevent phosphorus discharges from septic tanks  ::To create the supply and market in Ireland for magnesium rich brine from seawater, and for the use of magnesium oxide or Epsom salt, as an ingredient for the production of recycled phosphorus as struvite from separated urine.
Lobbying Activities: I met with Minister Malcolm Noonan at a recent EPA water conference. I have e mails politicians.   |Email|6-10

Specific Details: Concerns regarding the foreseeable and likely unintended consequences of the Assisted Decision Making (Capacity) Act 2015 for people seen/treated by psychiatrists
DPOs Lobbied: Stephen Donnelly|Minister|Department of Health::Roderic O'Gorman|Minister|Department of Children, Equality, Disability, Integration and Youth
Subject Matter: Concerns regarding the foreseeable and likely unintended consequences of the Assisted Decision Making (Capacity) Act 2015 for people seen/treated by psychiatrists
Intended Results:
Address 3 areas of specific concern that will impact patients and in Mental Health Services and a Register of valid Advance Healthcare Directives (AHD) needs to be created. ::There are three areas in particular of concern due to lack of regulation outlined - two areas where the failure to regulate AHDs will have a profound impact on the healthcare of the patients that psychiatrists regularly see as part of routine clinical practice, and a third area which we believe will worsen the existing health disparities faced by people with severe mental illness. 
Address concerns that as matters stand vulnerable groups will receive poorer mental and physical healthcare.

Specific Details: The Irish Association of Social Workers (IASW) is extremely concerned at the content of the latest report from the Child Law Project (CLP): Volume 1 2024 and calls for urgent action to be taken on the issues arising.
DPOs Lobbied: Roderic O'Gorman|Minister|Department of Children, Equality, Disability, Integration and Youth
Subject Matter: The Irish Association of Social Workers (IASW) is extremely concerned at the content of the latest report from the Child Law Project (CLP): Volume 1 2024 and calls for urgent action to be taken on the issues arising.
Intended Results: •	The urgent enactment and implementation of The Child Care (Amendment) Bill 2023, which would establish the best interests of the child to be of paramount consideration and introduce a duty to cooperate between relevant bodies including Tusla, HSE, Government Departments, and An Garda Síochána. This would ensure that state agencies such as the HSE would be legally obligated to work with Tusla to ensure that children in care are provided with much needed services in a more timely way. ::The establishment of an interdepartmental working group to urgently address the needs of children in care, many of whom are being repeatedly failed by state agencies to provide them with safe and consistent care as well as access to vital services identified to meet their individual needs. This group would address the underlying issues, including current deficiencies in interdepartmental and interagency cooperation and other factors like the recruitment and retention of staff and foster carers
